title: Although progress has been made, we noted that this was based on individual efforts
test_string: Although progress has been made, we noted that this was based on individual efforts
guidance: Avoid filler words: we noted

title: It was noted
guidance: Avoid filler words: was noted

title: We also noted an unusual number of rejected transactions
test_string: We also noted an unusual number of rejected transactions
guidance: Avoid filler words: also noted

title: Audit noted
guidance: Avoid filler words: Audit noted

title: As a result of the audit
regex: As a result of the audit
test_string: As a result of the audit
guidance: The readers know that, this is an audit report.

title: During our audit
guidance: The readers know that, this is an audit report.

title: During the audit
guidance: The readers know that, this is an audit report.

title: Based on the work performed
guidance: Do you absolutely need to tell the reader this?

title: appear
guidance: Can mean we haven't done enough work to support the conclusion.

title: seem
guidance: Can mean we haven't done enough work to support the conclusion.

title: around
guidance: Use precise words/numbers. "around" sounds woolly

title: we think
guidance: Subjective statement, word it as an objectively/fact-based statement if you can.

title: We have concluded that
guidance: Check if the agreed style is to use 'we' as opposed to the name of the department, etc.

title: don't
guidance: Expand to do not

title: doesn't
guidance: Expand to does not

title: won't
guidance: Expand to Will not

title: wouldn't
guidance: Expand to Would not

title: can't
guidance: Expand to Cannot

title: Haven't
guidance: Expand to Have not

title: I'll make it to lunch, however the day goes. Yes, your new shoes do match your outfit; however, they aren't weather-appropriate.
test_string: I'll make it to lunch, however the day goes. Yes, your new shoes do match your outfit; however, they aren't weather-appropriate.
guidance: Avoid mid-sentence use of however. Better at the start of a sentence to flag where the issue is. Also check if you can avoid it completely.

title: clear
guidance: Clear/Unclear may sound as if it was our fault, that we didn't understand. Go back to the basics/facts or use language that puts the burden on them.

title: inventorying
guidance: Bushism? Probably not a real word

title: clarity
guidance: It may sound as if it was our fault, that we didn't understand. Go back to the basics/facts or use language that puts the burden on them.

title: highlight
guidance: Have we used yellow or pink highlighter? Use simpler language if you can.

title: might
guidance: Vague, speculative

title: a number
guidance: Vague, add the actual number

title: numerous
guidance: Vague, add the actual number or some range

title: some
guidance: Vague, add specifics

title: few
guidance: Be specific if you can, put number. Few is relative to the reader

title: formally documented
guidance: Formally and documented may be overworking the point.

title: notwithstanding
guidance: Could a simpler term work?

title: furthermore
guidance: Could a simpler term work?

title: moreover
guidance: Could a simpler term work?

title: a degree
guidance: Vague, add specifics, commit

title: not all
guidance: Reader will think you live in an ivory tower and never ran a business in your life… of course, this is a large organization and "not all" cases will follow a rule, that's why there are exceptions. Give a sense of scale by including numbers and percentage (however crude), clarify if the issue is that the exceptions are not justified, or they didn't follow existing exception processes, or management cannot even report on how many didn't followed the expected behaviour.

title: several
guidance: Be specific, put the number

title: circa
guidance: Circa is used for dates, double check

title: drive
guidance: Consultancy lingo

title: lack of
guidance: Negative tones, use with caution.

title: maybe
guidance: Vague

title: has not been documented
guidance: Use active word, is the issue only documentation? Anything else we can say?

title: whilst
guidance: Could simpler words work?

title: wish
guidance: If you need to use the word wish in an audit report, better wish your boss has mercy

title: retain
guidance: Could you use keep?

title: Based on the audit
guidance: The readers know that, this is an audit report.

title: in order
guidance: Often overused

title: therefore
guidance: Could you use "so", "then", "hence"?

title: in order to
guidance: Could you use "to"?

title: surrounding
guidance: Simpler word?

title: \nLimited assurance report
guidance: Double check, what "limited" means exactly, is it a limited scope? We live in a world of limited resource, are you trying to say "not fit for purpose" or "insufficient"?

title: . Limited liability should be sought
guidance: Double check, what "limited" means exactly, is it a limited scope? We live in a world of limited resource, are you trying to say "not fit for purpose" or "insufficient"?

title: There was limited value in implementing this feature. Limited budget led to delays and incomplete functionality ultimately being deployed.
test_string: There was limited value in implementing this feature. Limited budget led to delays and incomplete functionality ultimately being deployed.
guidance: Double check, what "limited" means exactly, is it a limited scope? We live in a world of limited resource, are you trying to say "not fit for purpose" or "insufficient"?

title: limited assurance
guidance: Possible back-covering?

title: Internal Audit have completed an audit of the sales process
test_string: Internal Audit have completed an audit of the sales process
guidance: Check  preferred style , some Directors prefer "has"

title: there needs to be
guidance: Prefer shorter/active voice

title: strong focus
guidance: Padding, could you use just "focus"

title: regarding
guidance: Could you use "about"

title: assist
guidance: Could you use help? … you need help, yes.

title: However doomed the relationship, an open heart is its own reward.
test_string: However doomed the relationship, an open heart is its own reward.
guidance: Missing comma? Check if you can avoid/reduce its use.

title: over
guidance: Check if you are not "over" using it, Make the wording punchier.

title: historically
guidance: Avoid if possible, maybe use "past"?

title: formally
guidance: Check if you can put something more than just a point on formalities

title: underpin
guidance: What that exactly means? Difficult words make it harder to the reader, also consider that non-native speakers may be reading this report.

title: ensure
guidance: Check if we shouldn't say "provide assurance …" Or the shorter "make sure"

title: commence
guidance: Could you use start?

title: in relation to
guidance: Could you use a shorter glue word?

title: governance
guidance: Often misused or too generic, double check if it is sufficiently explained.

title: Celebrate failure; it means you took a risk
test_string: Celebrate failure; it means you took a risk
guidance: Do you really need a semicolon?

title: sensitive
guidance: Be careful with this term, if we are referring to data, prefer using the standard data classification labels… confidential, restricted confidential, etc. Or ensure the reader knows exactly what kInd of data are we talking about.

title: regular
guidance: Check if you need to clarify actual frequency

title: frequent
guidance: Check if you need to clarify the actual frequency

title: partial
guidance: Ensure the reader understand what partially means, what is the residual risk or aspect that is NOT covered

title: to action
guidance: If used as a verb consider "do" or other more specific word

title: will action
guidance: If used as a verb consider "do" or other more specific word

title: have actioned
guidance: If used as a verb consider "do" or other more specific word

title: generally
guidance: Use with care

title: broadly
guidance: Use with care

title: typically
guidance: Use with care

title: even
guidance: Check if we are not being speculative or too colloquial.

title: Heresy!  Double spaces after a period.  Or even more   ?
test_string: Heresy!  Double spaces after a period.  Or even more   ?
guidance: Double spaces

title: Space before the period .
guidance: Space before period

title: To be , or not to be.
test_string: To be , or not to be.
guidance: Space before comma

title: Space before a colon :
guidance: Space before colon

title: Audit performed a review of the sales process
test_string: Audit performed a review of the sales process
guidance: Check if "review" is the right word. Readers have been confused by the term (audit vs review)

title: achieving
guidance: LT removed it in the exec summary of a weak report, check if the tone is right, maybe it sounded patronising and/or a more neutral factual wording was appropriate.

title: deliver
guidance: Consider "Implement" or "Establish" or better yet "Embed" (to allow time to mature)

title: establish
guidance: Check if we are all on the same page regarding what  "establish"  means (e.g. same as embed? Or just "implement"). Consider specific factual elements that we would take as evidence of something being established.

title: require
guidance: Check if "Need" or other direct words may work better in this context.

title: need
guidance: Use "Require"?  "Need" is direct/informal and may or may not be the right tone depending on the context.

title: robust
guidance: Could you use "rigorous" or consistent, mature, reliable, embedded, verifiable, resilient, funded (if we are talking plans), effective?

title: unable to
guidance: Make sure it is truly the case, and if so, explain why, especially if it refers to us.

title: not able
guidance: Make sure it is truly the case, and if so, explain why, especially if it refers to us.

title: not possible
guidance: Make sure it is truly the case, and if so, explain why, especially if it refers to us.

title: It is possible that
guidance: Use can, might, could, may.

title: not been possible
guidance: Make sure it is truly the case, and if so, explain why, especially if it refers to us.

title: consider
guidance: A "soft" word that may give too much room for not doing nothing or refer to "thinking" activity. Prefer action related words… include, address, remediate, comply with, document, etc.

title: has not been
guidance: Prefer active voice, who should have done whatever

title: coming months
guidance: Can you be more precise on timeframes

title: In the short term, we need short-term measures
test_string: In the short term, we need short-term measures
guidance: Can you be more precise on timeframes

title: In the medium term, we need medium-term initiatives
test_string: In the medium term, we need medium-term initiatives
guidance: Can you be more precise on timeframes

title: In the long term, we need long term strategic programmes
test_string: In the long term, we need long term strategic programmes
guidance: Can you be more precise on timeframes

title: These are considerations for the longer term.
test_string: These are considerations for the longer term.
guidance: Can you be more precise on timeframes
Prefer dates with explicit month, check the style guidelines.

title: obtain
guidance: Could you use get?

title: identify
guidance: Could you use find?

title: notify
guidance: Could you use tell?

title: prior to
guidance: Could you use before?

title: remain
guidance: Could you use keep or stay?

title: receive
guidance: Could you use take?

title: cease
guidance: Could you … stop?

title: demonstrate
guidance: Could you use prove or show?

title: collaborate
guidance: Could you use shorter versions? Work together, help.

title: understand
guidance: Check if this is not referring to people not understanding something. It can be taken badly by readers. Use if absolutely clear/supported

title: understood
guidance: Check if this is not referring to people not understanding something. It can be taken badly by readers. Use if absolutely clear/supported

title: basic
guidance: Are you sure the reader understand what Basic means

title: management indicated
guidance: Are we clear on whether we have verified/is evidenced of we are taking their statement at face value

title: management stated
guidance: Are we clear on whether we have verified/is evidenced of we are taking their statement at face value

title: mitigat
guidance: The term mitigation could be confusing, check it is clear if partial or full. If partial make sure to explain the residual risk

title: key
guidance: Check you are not padding or overusing

title: relevant
guidance: Check you are not padding or overusing

title: appropriate
guidance: Check if needed.

title: policies
guidance: Check if it is clear which policies are we talking about (enterprise vs local, standards vs true "policies")

title: All of the
guidance: Use "All the"

title: Commonly referred as
guidance: Avoid where possible

title: Due to the fact that
guidance: Use Because

title: In terms of the funding needed…
test_string: In terms of the funding needed…
guidance: Use "regarding" or "about"

title: With regard to
guidance: Use "regarding" or "about"

title: With reference to
guidance: Use "regarding" or "about"

title: The fact that
guidance: Restructure to focus on the actual statement

title: Needless to say
guidance: Remove

title: It is important to note
guidance: Remove

title: In the event that
guidance: Prefer "if"

title: There is
guidance: Prefer active voice

title: It is
guidance: Prefer active voice

title: There has been
guidance: Prefer active voice

title: There have been
guidance: Prefer active voice

title: At all times
guidance: Remove

title: There is no appetite for
guidance: Check if there is enough context for the reader. Often it refers to a specific risk appetite statement, or to tolerances.
